Polygonal Structures This chapter presents the data structures for the surfaces that are used in the SimplicialSurfaces-package. More accurately, it presents the structures (which can be much more general than simplicial surfaces) that are build from polygons.
These structures are described as DiscreteComplexes. To model these structures there are two main options:
Description by incidence geometry. This leads to the concept of PolygonalComplex (section ). The requirements for these to be surfaces are explained in section .
If incidence geometry is not sufficient to describe a polygonal structure, additional information (subdivision of faces) can be used. This leads to the concept of BendPolygonalComplex (section ). The weaker properties of the incidence geometry are explained in section .

Surfaces are a special case of polygonal complexes and the package provides functionality to determine whether a polygonal complex is a surface.
Polygonal Complexes (pure incidence geometry) A polygonal complex is defined by a two-dimensional incidence geometry that fulfills some regularity conditions (the complete definition will be given at the end of this section in definition ). We will exemplify this by the following surface.
\begin{tikzpicture}[vertexStyle=nolabels, edgeStyle=nolabels, faceStyle=nolabels] \input{Image_StarOfStarExample.tex} \end{tikzpicture}
In a two-dimensional incidence geometry we have a set V of vertices, a set E of edges and a set F of faces. If we label our surface like this,
\begin{tikzpicture}[vertexStyle, edgeStyle, faceStyle] \input{Image_StarOfStarExample.tex} \end{tikzpicture}
we have the sets
V = \{2, 3, 5, 7, 11\}
E = \{6, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13\}
F = \{I, IV\}.
These sets can't encode the surface on their own. The relations between vertices, edges, and faces are also necessary. Therefore we define a transitive relation in the union of V \times E, V \times F, and E \times F, where (a,b) is in the relation if and only if a is incident to b. Since the relation is transitive, it is sufficient to specify the tuples in V \times E and E \times F. In our example the relation is generated by
\{ (2,6), (2,8), (3,8), (3,9), (3,12), (5,6), (5,9), (5,10), (7,12), (7,13), (11,10), (11,13)\}
and
\{ (6,I), (8,I), (9,I), (9,IV), (10,IV), (12,IV), (13,IV) \}.
However, we do not permit arbitrary incidence relations but only those satisfying certain regularity conditions (like in our example). For example, every edge should consist of exactly two vertices (more formally, for every edge there should be exactly two vertices that are incident to it).
\begin{tikzpicture}[vertexStyle, edgeStyle] \coordinate (A) at (0,0); \coordinate (B) at (3,1);
\draw[edge] (A) -- (B);
\foreach \p/\r/\n in {A/left/2, B/right/3}{ \vertexLabelR{\p}{\r}{\n} } \end{tikzpicture}
If we try to generalize this condition to the faces we encounter some difficulties. For example, if we only enforce that each face has exactly three edges and three vertices, it would be possible that two of those edges share all of their vertices. Therefore even the case of triangles is quite complicated.
\begin{tikzpicture}[vertexStyle, edgeStyle=nolabels] \def\xs{2} \coordinate (A) at (0,0); \coordinate (B) at (\xs,1); \coordinate (C) at (2*\xs,0);
\draw[edge] (A) to [bend left=30] (B); \draw[edge] (A) to [bend right=30] (B); \draw[edge] (B) -- (C);
\foreach \p/\r/\n in {A/left/1, B/above/2, C/right/3}{ \vertexLabelR{\p}{\r}{\n} } \end{tikzpicture}

With these conditions we have guaranteed that all edges and faces behave as in our previous example. But they still allow the possibility of an incidence relation where we have vertices but no faces. Since we want to exclude singular cases like this from our considerations, we require that every vertex is incident to at least one edge and that every edge is incident to at least one face.

Polygonal and simplicial surfaces Polygonal surfaces are polygonal complexes (compare section ) that behave like surfaces (two-dimensional manifolds with boundary). For example, they arise from the discretisation of a continuous surface. Simplicial surfaces are polygonal surfaces, where all polygons are triangles.
There are two properties that distinguish polygonal surfaces from polygonal complexes:
Every edge behaves "like a surface", i.e. it is incident to at most two faces. This excludes cases like three triangles that share one edge.
